They were searching for that child.
Give the letter to that [person].
He is running from here.
I found a lot of scrubhen [eggs] there.
He sat there, on the rock.

The girls dug up a lot of pipis.
He was asking around for food among his friends.
The wives said to them:
Go to get some fish!

items.transcript: N gamu-karra nganjan-karra school-mun-bu dunga-y teacher-mun-unji balka-wa-nka.
items.translation: The mothers and fathers go to the school to talk with the teacher.
The two women burnt the ghost with [burning] grass trees.
The pair of horses is coming.
Two horses are running to the river.
A pair of trees is standing there.
I saw two trees.
Sea-turtle meat is softer than beef.
I am very hungry.
The baby is very cute.
The very strong man lifted the pig up.
I am sorry for the very sick child.
I go for a walk with the childless one.
They came back with the mothers' clothes.
A ghost stole the two women's children.
The Banabila-people's dogs are fierce.
Don't go with that drunkard!
The boss is talking with the young men.
The pregnant woman's husband died.
He ran [off] with the policeman's rifle.
The very big man's spear broke.
He went with a very old car.

With respect to the surroundings of the settlement at W ujal W ujal on the Bloomfield River, wangkar refers to 'up the river' and bada to 'down the river'. When indicating direction 'up a mountain' or a downward path other than along the river valley, the general direction marker yarra together with an appropriate gesture is used in connection with wangkar or bada. In an extended sense, wangkar refers to a place or direction 'above speaker (in the air, in a tree, etc.)' and bada to a place 'below speaker (on the ground, under water, etc.)'.
(my) right side
left foot
The police took my father "Cairns-way".
Mary is standing close to Queenie.
He came from the other side of the river.
I hear a song from a long way away.
People are singing out from down there.
The old woman followed him.
The young man jumped [out] from behind the tree.
He became ill yesterday.
Tomorrow he will go to see the doctor.
I keep some food for later on today.
He has been keeping some old clothes from a long time [ago].
He got a rock and set it up for the next time.
I hit Carol with them
I saw his elder brother.
My dog bit a child.
My dog bit a child.
I like your mother very much.
Give this money to your [dual] father!
A policeman is coming from their house.
He took your child's food.

items.transcript: N gayku-wun-bul-du babarr-andamun-du kaya-ngka ngayku minya ngaki-ny.
items.translation: My elder sister's dog stole my meat.
Why did you take the dog into the house? (and not somewhere else)

items.transcript: Wanyurringku yundu kaya wundi-ny bayan-ba, ngalkal-ba-ku bawa-nyaku.
items.translation: What did you take the dog into the house for, you should have left it outside.
What are you ill with?
Where is your mother?
Where are you going?

items.transcript: Yunu scissors wundi! Ngayku scissors wanjabu.
items.translation: Bring (take) your scissors! My scissors are somewhere (I don't know where I put them).
How did you come back?
How do you cook freshwater eel?
Which one is your house?
What kind of fish did they get?
What kind of people are they?

items.transcript: Yundu wanjanguy-ngku kambi-ka wawu, yinya-ka nganka-nganka-jirr-ka?
items.translation: Which kind of dress do you like, the one with the flower pattern?
This woman taught me about zamia nuts.
He sat there, on the rock.
The young man is splitting firewood.
A thunderstorm will come soon.
The man sharpened the knife.
The Aborigine turned back and came back to his camp.
The child fell ill.
Don't chase the horse!
Put your pants on!
Put the baby on the blanket!
Wash your hands!
Learn language!
Heat [it] up!
Don't drop [it]!
I would go/would have gone fishing [but I cannot for some reason].

items.transcript: N gayu nuka-nyaku minya, kari yinya minya kabu.
items.translation: I would have eaten that meat, but it was rotten.

gloss.gloss: I want to cook some food

items.translation: I want to cook some food.
He knows how to spear.

items.transcript: Jana makarr wundi-ny kuyu wubul bangka-nka.
items.translation: They took a net to catch a lot of fish.
I go with a friend lest I get lonely.
Bum some ironwood to prevent the thunderstorm from coming!
They had finished the food before [their] father woke up.
He cried out before he died.

items.transcript: N gayu bambay-ma-ny mayngku kayal nuka-nya.
items.translation: I became sick from eating unripe mangoes.
They keep the word/message secret.
The child made the clothes dirty.
The child made the water dirty.
The girl overcooked the food.
Stoke the fire again !
Leave me alone!
He eloped with that woman.
Mother mistakenly sent the child to school (it was still too young).

The wood turned into charcoal.
He went on again and moved eastwards.
He is moving into the sun.
I became an old woman.
Eventually Leonie will get married.
My house will move into the sun.
The two snakes wrap around each other.
The women are fighting; they stir each other up with a dance.
He does not want to fight.
That man talks a lot, he is a chatterbox.
The man paints himself for the corroboree.
The cat is stretching itself.
I stretch the cat.
All sorts of people turned up.
You lot, come here!
The children hide in the house.
He killed the wallaby with one shot.
The police came discreetly.

items.transcript: Kari bunda-y! Ngarri buyun. Yunu-nji nguyarr dara-y.
items.translation: Don't sit down! [The bench] has a rotten leg. It will tip over with you.
I did not quite hit the tree with the stone (but the stone may have touched it in passing).
You look just right living in that caravan.
The rope is lying coiled up.
The old horse is walking slowly.
He quickly followed the stranger.
Put the eggs carefully on the plate!

items.transcript: N gayu warru-ku Palm Island bundanda-ny.
items.translation: As a young man I stayed at Palm Island.

items.transcript: N gayu karrkay-nyja-ku minya kadar ngangkin nuka-l-nuka-ny.
items.translation: As a child I used to eat wallaby and porcupine.
The man murdered him (intended to kill).
He looks like a pig.
Some places are just the same [as this place].
The old man also cried for his wife [just like the others].
I did not really sleep (I just dozed).

items.transcript: Jana kada-ny, kuyu mani-ny, waju-ny, nuka-ny-da.
items.translation: They came, caught a fish, cooked [it], and then ate [it].
He caught a fish first, then speared a turtle.
The girl washed all the clothes thoroughly.
Sweep the whole house thoroughly!
I want to speak only to you.
Only the Islander felt sorry afterwards.
I am living by myself.
He is getting quite sick.
The blue tongue lizard bit the taipan again.
I want to come back.
it's up to you
I give you money and you, in tum, give me meat.
It's your tum to sit down, I sweep the yard.

items.transcript: Monday yindu ngayu-ji school-mun-bu dunga-ny, mayi waju-nku.
items.translation: Last Monday it was my tum to go to the school to cook food [i.e. school lunch].

items.translation: I squeeze the fruit like this with my hand.

items.translation: Aborigines teach me about [their] language, "bush-tucker", land [and] Aboriginal people.

items.translation: The big grey kangaroo is like the boss of Australia.

items.translation: I will send your food with my mother.

items.transcript: Babarr-angka mayi waju-l, jinkurr-ungku eZ-ERG:pt(A) food.ABS(O) cook-NONPAST yZ-ERG:pt(A) ngawa nyaji-l-nyaji-l.
items.translation: Elder sister is cooking food andlwhile younger sister is watching the baby.

items.transcript: N gayu yarraman karrba-l, yundu daka-l.
items.translation: I hold the horse andlwhile you climb up.

items.transcript:
Nyulu yindu nyunba-ny-baja, kangkal-kangkal
nyungu wubul-ku mani-ny, wundi-ny badabada
bayan-ba, camp-LOC milbi-ny-da.
items.translation: The other one turned back again, fetched her many children, brought them down to the camp and showed them.
[If] you had come, you would have seen me.

items.transcript: Bula warru-ngku nambarr kulba-ny, kaja-ny, dunga-ny-baja.
items.translation: The two young men pulled out the bamboo, wrapped it up and went on again.

items.transcript: Nyulu dingkar bunda-ny, minya-nga nuka-ji-ny, wunana-ny-da.
items.translation: The man sat down, had a good feed of meat and then had a rest.
The man came in and the woman hit him.
The man entered and the woman happened to hit [him].

items.transcript: Ngayu buwun-ji dunga-ny, kari muyar junkuji.
items.translation: I went out with a boat, but there was a strong wind.

items.transcript: lalbu yinya wawu baduri-ji dunga-nka, kari nyulu bambay.
items.translation: That woman would like to go fishing, but she is sick.

items.transcript: N gayu nyaji-nka yinya bama, kari kalakalbay-bajaku.
items.translation: I am trying to see that person, but [he is] too far away.

items.transcript: Nyulu warru-ngku kuyu mani-ny, kari burrki-n-burrki-n.
items.translation: The young man got the fish [on the line], but [it] kept on fidgeting/struggling.
That port (suitcase) is small, but [it] is heavy.

items.transcript: Kaki yundu yinya kaya juku-bu kuni-l, yununybayka-l.
items.translation: If you hit that dog with a stick, [it] will bite you.

items.transcript: Kaki ngayu ngiki-ji, ngayu yangka dumbarri-l, nuka-l.
items.translation: If I have a cough/cold, I break up green ants and eat [them].

items.transcript: Nyulu warngku-wuna-y, kaki nyulu bangkarr bajaburray.
items.translation: He has a sleep, if he feels tired.
(If/when) he was exhausted, he had a sleep.

items.transcript: Ngayu bana wundi-l, kunka/nganganjirrka bana kari baral-darr.
items.translation: I take some water in case there is no water along the road.

items.transcript: Ngayu bana wundi-l. Yinya-ngkarr bana yambakari.
items.translation: I take some water. There is no water at all along the road.

items.transcript: Nyulu ngayku kambi julurri-l, ngayu-ji nyungu-nku mayi waju-l.
items.translation: She washes my clothes and I in turn cook food for her.

items.transcript: Jalbu-ngku nganya kuni-ny, ngayu-ji nyunguny kuni-ny.
items.translation: The woman hit me and I in turn hit her [back].
I'd better cook some food. [I am] hungry.

items.transcript: Ngayku balji kadaba-ny. Ngayu balji jirakal balka-nka.
items.translation: My bag is broken. I have to make a new bag.
You two get some grass for the soup!
You two get some grass for eating the soup!
The child moves and as a result gets born.
The women sat down to have a chat.
The young man went to the river to spear fish.
The woman stood up so that [her] husband could see her.
He asked [his] friends to give [him] some food.
Mother is cooking fish in order to eat [it].
Grandmother drinks green ant [prepended context implies ‘to get better’].
I spread a sheet to sit on.
I beat (on) the tree so that the people can hear [me].
I summoned/ordered the woman to give [me] some clams.
Elder sister is making a bag for mother to carry.
The police summoned the young man to come.
Grandmother told the girl to look after the baby.
Elder brother told [his] younger sister to run.
The woman told [her] niece to light a fire.
He goes to the new house to have a peep [at it].
I go to the boss to ask [him].
Granny takes the child so that [he/she/it] be happy.
Granny takes the child to gather firewood.

items.transcript: Kami-ngka maral wundi-ny, nyulu kambi nyungu mani-nka.
items.translation: Granny took the girl so that she (the girl) will get her clothes.
I light a fire so that you get warm.

items.transcript: Dunyu-ngku kamukamu kari nuka-l, manyarr wawurrwawurr-ma-nka.
items.translation: The husband does not drink alcohol so that [his] wife is happy.
He wants some meat.
He wants to eat.
He wants to eat meat.
I want them to get some turtle.
I am afraid of the dark.
I am afraid to go out in the dark.
This is drinking water/water for drinking.
That is rubbish for burning.
There is dust in the drinking water.

items.transcript: Yanya bana nuka-nka, yarnba bulbur bana-nga.
items.translation: This is drinking water, but there is dust in the water.
He does not bathe in the river lest [he] drown.

items.transcript: Kari kalka-ji nguju-wuri-y, yundu ngawa kuni-nyji
items.translation: Don't play/fool around with the spear lest you hit the baby!

items.transcript: BamaAborigine.ABS(S) kari jikan-baNEG grass-LOC kalbay-mba dunga-n-dunga-y,long-LOC go-n-REDUP-NONPAST
items.translation: Aborigines don't walk through long grass lest a snake bite [them].
Young men don't drink alcohol lest [they] fight.
Don't cook the food lest you spoil [it]!
Don't touch the vicious dog lest [it] bite [you].

items.transcript: Babarr-angka karrkay-karrkay kanga-ny, nyunguny kuni-nyji. Karrkay kuli-baka.
items.translation: Elder sister chases the children away, lest they hit her. The children are a wild lot.
I carry the baby lest [it] cry.

items.transcript: Bula jalbu-ngku dubu waJu-ny, kangkal ngaki-nyji-baja.
items.translation: The two women burnt the ghost lest [he] steal [their] children again.
Don't pick up the egg lest you drop [it]!

items.transcript: Nyulu wawu kari kaya-nda dunga-nka, (kaya-ngka)/(nyulu) bayka-nyji.
items.translation: He doesn't want to go to the dog, lest (the dog)/(it) bite [him].
Keep a fire burning lest it get cold!
That fish might get rotten.

items.transcript: Ngayu jinbal-da-ku jarba kuni-ny, nganya bayka-nyjiku.
items.translation: I quickly killed the snake before [it] might bite me.
I had a rest before going for a walk.

items.transcript: lalbu mara julurri-ji-y, mayi damba dingka-nyjiku.
items.translation: The woman washes [her] hands before kneading damper.
The girl stocks up clothes before getting married.
She sweeps the ground before setting up camp.
The women roast the zamia nuts before pounding them.

items.transcript: Ngayu kaya karrba-ny, nyulu ngayku minya bangkarr nuka-nyjiku.
items.translation: I grabbed the dog before it ate my steak.
They saw the wallaby before it ran away.
A bird cries before rain falls, [that is] the rainbird.
I went before the wind came.

items.transcript: Nganjin bibikarrbi wunana-ny, ngayku nganjan wundi-nyjiku waybala-ngka Palm Island.
items.translation: We were living at Helenvale before white people took my father to Palm Island.
I have a sore back while/from gathering firewood.

items.transcript: Ngayu muku kaka, baya muja-nya yilayku.
items.translation: I have a sore back from gathering firewood yesterday.
He is tired from bathing.
He choked from gobbling down food.
The policeman did not see me because [he] was asleep.
Elder sister is searching for the child because [she] lost [it].
The two took the child (with them) because (it) felt lonely.

items.transcript: N ganjan-angka kangkal murrukanga-l, kaya jabi-nya, (nyulu)
items.translation: Father is scolding [his] child because [it] kicked the dog.
After bathing, they have a rest.
We saw the woman after [she] had come in.
The man killed the Brown Snake after [it] had bitten [him].
I had a rest after washing clothes.
She went for a walk after having fed the chickens.
The young man grabbed the dog after it had barked (lit. after the barking).
She drank some water after the walk.
They won't go in case it starts raining.

items.transcript: Ngayu1sg bayanhouse kida-l sweep dayirr-bunga-l kunkain ngayku1sg jawunfriend kada-nya-mun-ku
items.translation: I sweep the house and clean it in case my friend comes [to visit].

items.transcript: Ngaji-ngka medicine wundi-l baral-ka kunka nyulu bambay-ma-nya-mun-ku
items.translation: Grandfather takes medicine for the road in case he gets sick.

items.transcript: Maral-angka junkalu wundi-ny kunka nyungu-ndu girl-ERG:pt(A) billycan.ABS(O) take-PAST janbal nyaji-ji-nya-mun-ku quandong.ABS(S) see-ITR -SUB-mun-DAT
items.translation: The girl took a billycan in case she came across some quandong fruit.

items.transcript: Kalnga-ngka juku-ji dunga-y kunka kaya-ngka nyunguny bayka-nya-mun-ku
items.translation: Uncle goes with (takes) a stick in case the dog bites (attacks) him.

items.transcript: N gayu marrkin wundi-l nguba 1sg.NOM(A) gun.ABS(O) take-NONPAST perhaps 1sg-LOC bikibiki nyaJl-Jl-Y. see-I1R-NONPAST
items.translation: I take a gun, perhaps (I) happen to see some pigs.
A thunderstorm struck the cow [which was/while it was] standing on the mountain.

items.transcript: Buliman-angka warru karrba-ny, janjarri-I-janjarri-nya. snoop-I-REDUP-SUB bayan
items.translation: The policeman apprehended the chap [who was/while he was] snooping in the house.

items.transcript: Nyulu dingkar nyaji-l-nyaji-ny, bana wulji-l-wulji-nya buwun-muny
items.translation: He watched the man [who was] bailing water from the boat.

items.transcript: Nyulu nyaji-l-nyaji-ny, dingkar-angka bana wulji-l-wulji-inya buwun-muny
items.translation: He watched [while] the man was bailing water from the boat.
The girl watches the bird [while] standing up.

items.transcript: Nyulu jalbu-ngku dunyu bawa-ny. Nyulu yinyay bundanda-y kangkal-ji
items.translation: The woman left her husband. She [who] is sitting there with her child.

items.transcript: Nyulu yinya mala-minya. Nyulu bama wawubaja-nga dunga-y
items.translation: That one is a good hunter. The Aborigine [who] is walking to the river.

items.transcript: Ngayu ngawuya wawu daji-nka ngayku-wun-du. Nyulu yilayku kada-ny
items.translation: I want to give turtle [meat] to my friend. He [who] came yesterday.
I go to the river to catch a fish...
... lest I get hungry.
... in case I get hungry.
... before I clean the house.
... after I clean the house.
Father's dog is running fast.
The scales of the fish are big and plentiful.
The fish of in (lit. of) the river are good.
The man's elder brother killed a pig.
I am learning about Aborigines' food.
We put everything into Chris's Toyota.
I don't like your father's dog.
His hair is wet.
He hooked the fish (on) the tail.
He dropped the stone on the girl's foot.
I have two children.
I have many granddaughters.
The leaves on this tree/from this tree are very big.
Fruit onlfrom that tree is good to eat.
The shell on/of/*from the zamia nut is hard.
That is my former husband.
That house formerly belonged to a woman.

items.transcript: Bula jalbu-bulal-angka mayi kubarr daji-ny dingkar-anda
items.translation: The two women gave the eel to the man.
I gave mother [her] food.
That dog is vicious.
The child needs to have a pee.
The sea is rough.
The egg has a soft shell.
That man has a beard.
They are people of light forest country.
The woman has many clothes.
That man has three spears.
hot season
cold season
His grandfather died in the hot season.
The young man killed the vicious snake.
The man with the beard speared many mullet.
I like very much the tree with the many big leaves.
Grandmother gave green ant [juice] to the child with the cough.
He came from that house with the tree.
I came with [my] aunt.
The young men are going out for pigs with a dog/dogs.
She is sitting in the house with the baby.
He went down the river with a dinghy.
The old man is going out with a spear and an axe.
[Our] friend is sitting with papers/books and a tape-recorder.
That dog is playing with a bone.
The young man is dancing with his younger sister.
They are stupid.
J don't have a cold, [I am] well again.
The old woman has no teeth.
The one without hair stole my shoes.
The homeless one is sad.
We have no tea.
J gave clothes to the childless woman.
He went without a rifle.
The baby sleeps without a blanket.

items.transcript: Ngayu kari jilba-dunga-y jalbu-nji, ngayu-rrku dunga-y.
items.translation: J don't go walkabout with the women, J go by myself.
Wash yourselves !
Don't blame [your] mother !
Drop that!
(You two) keep sitting there, I will come back.
Come on, let's go now!
Eat straight away (before you do anything else)!
Have you seen my child?
Did he come back?
Who came with the boss?
Who took my shoes?
With whom did you go to Cooktown?
What did you put in the bag?
What (sort of) food do you want/like?
Where is he from?
When will you come back, (in the) hot season?
How many Aborigines live there?
They don't know the language nowadays.
The woman knows how to weave dillybags.
The man is good at/with cattle.
I'm afraid of crocodiles.
The children love to play.
He wants to make a spear.
The child wantsllikes to hide.
I learn language.
The old women taught me about food (and) how to dig scrub hen (eggs).
I did not break the billycan.
I did not break the billycan [but something else].
I did not break the billycan [but something else did].
Not a ghost is coming, [but] a man.
The young man could not spear the turtle.
I don't like fighting.
I don't like to smoke.
I don't like half-ripe mangoes.
He is (just) like his father.
Eskimos are expert hunters like Aborigines.

items.transcript: Ngayu wawu jirray mayi-ka yala mayngku.
items.translation: I like very much fruit [that is] like a mango.

items.transcript: N gayu mayi wundi-ny yala nyulu ngadiku
items.translation: I brought food like he brought it long ago.

items.transcript: Jana wanjabu? N guba jana ngaki-ji-y.
items.translation: Where are they? Maybe they are hiding.

items.transcript: Nguba ngayu nyiku kada-y-baja, nguba wunkuny.
items.translation: Maybe I come back today (or) maybe tomorrow.

items.transcript: guba ngayu kuyu nyama-l, nguba dinda-l.
items.translation: Maybe I'll stew the fish, maybe [I'll] roast it.
My elder brother and I caught a lot of fish.
You and Roderick have a swim!
A pair of two young fellows ...
You and I and the children will go walkabout tomorrow.

items.transcript: Ngayu babi wulbuman yindu ngamu nganjin dunga-ri-ny mayi baka-nka
items.translation: I, grandmother, another old woman and mother, we went out to dig for food (yams).
We all including Mabel had a long chat.
You children go and get water!

items.transcript: Jalbu-jalbu karrkay-karrkay jana wawubaja-nga dunga-ny mukirr mani-nka
items.translation: Women and children, they went to the river to get mussels.
Doris and her people came back.
The child was sleeping.
His camp was on top of the mountain.
There was this old man.
Grandmother missed [the fish] with the digging stick.

items.transcript: Ngayu-ji-ku-lu naybu-bu-ku I bana-nga-kuda wadu-kuda nyanda-ny.
items.translation: While I in tum hacked vainly in the water with a knife.

items.transcript: Nganjin wawubaja-nga kada-ny tent ngara-ny mayi nuka-ny wuna-ny-da.
items.translation: We came to the river, set up tent, ate some food and then rested.
I first cook the fish and then I take it [with me].
Queenie was the first to find (lit. get) an egg.
After the sleep they went on.
Since that time I have grown up.
They came to the Jeannie River.

items.transcript: Bulakada-ny, bula wawubaja-nga dunga-ny.3du.NOM(S) come-PAST 3du.NOM(S) river-LOC go-PAST
items.translation: They came and they went to the river.

items.transcript: Bula wawubaja-nga dunga-ny, bula mayi3du.NOM(S) river-LOC go-PAST 3du.NOM(A) fruit.ABS(O)kabal warrmba-bunga-ny.Leichardt.tree.ABS(O) uncovered-CAUS-PAST
items.translation: They went to the river and they found some Leichardt tree fruit.
Leichardt fruit [they] found.

items.transcript: Nyulu jina yijarri-ny murraJa-nga / Nyunguniny murraja-bu baka-ny.
items.translation: He put [his] foot on a stonefish. The stonefish poked him.

items.transcript: Chris kangkal-bulal dingkar-bulal ngayku; kangkal-kangkal, ngayu janangan murrukanga-ny.
items.translation: I scolded them, Chris and my two sons:
Some were killed ...
The woman looked after the child.
[He] pushed the really big rock and set it up.
Right on the road [he] set the big rock.
He sat and watched.

items.transcript: Waybala janyiman, jana Palmer River kada-ny mani-nka.
items.translation: White men and Chinese, they came to the Palmer River to get gold.
White men, they killed many Aborigines.

items.transcript: BamaAborigine wubul,many waybala-ngkawhite.man-ERG:pt(A) janangan3pl.ACC(O) kuni-l-kuni-ny. kill-l-REDUP-PAST
items.translation: Many Aborigines, the white men killed them.

items.transcript: Bakarrmuku-muny kada-ny, kada-ny kada-ny kada-ny, Wakooka.Stn-ABL, bula yuwulbuwun kada-ny
items.translation: [They] came from Wakooka Station, came on and on and on, they came to the Jeannie River.

items.transcript: Dunga-ny-da wulbuman wangkar dunga-ny kaya-nda mani-nka
items.translation: Off went the old woman (leaving the two young fellows), went up to the dog to get [it].
They came and they went to the river.
We could not follow, the fish was swimming in the water.

items.transcript: Kari ngamu-ngku-lu / juwal-da dama! / digging.stick-INST spear-IMP
items.translation: But mother said: "You two spear it with a digging stick!"

items.transcript: Ngali kuwa-muny kada-ri-ny. / UN gay, kari wangkar-muny ngayu kankada-ny.
items.translation: We two came from the West. I see, but I came from up there.

items.transcript: Walkarr kul-ji kari, / yamba dirra kabu nuka-nya
items.translation: The black goanna is not vicious, but [its] teeth are full of germs from eating rotten meat.

items.transcript: J ana mala-minya / bubu walu-yindu / yala bama, yamba jana-nga
items.translation: They (the Eskimos) are good hunters and fishermen like Aborigines, but their country is different.

items.transcript: Balu yundu minya dinda-nka, / bana-nga waju-l kari yundu
items.translation: I thought you intended to roast the meat, but you are boiling it in water.
I thought he was coming back (but apparently he did not).

items.transcript:
Warru-bulal jambul, bula jilba-dunga-ny
dunga-ny dunga-ny,
items.translation: Two young men, they went walkabout, went on and on,
they came from the West, from somewhere (around) Wakooka Station.
they came to the Jeannie River.

items.transcript: Yundu dunga-y, yundu Palmer River kada-y
items.translation: You go, and you come to the Palmer River.

items.transcript: Yundu Palmer River kada-y, yundu yarra
items.translation: You come to the Palmer River and you see over there somewhere a higher mountain top, [that is] Mount Windsor.
His camp [was] up there on the mountain top.
He lived in a cave.
He used to get up early and sit around.
[He] looked around to see smoke.
The policemen were going along,
(they were) lighting grassfires.
[Thus] he got to know: “Ah, that's the police!”
He came.
[He] went down there and sat and sat.
[He] followed them behind, followed and followed.
They stopped and set up camp,
hobbled the horses, set up camp, settled down.
In the dark [he] came, he sneaked up with a rifle.

items.transcript: Nyulu marrkin-ji karangaji-nya kuni-nya jananiny marrkin-da.
items.translation: He sneaked up with a rifle and shot [at] them with the rifle.
They said: "Hey, that's him!"
[He would] shoot [and he was] good at getting away.
The child was sleeping.
Mother and father were sleeping.

items.transcript: Ah wuna-ny wuna-ny, Ah lie-PAST lie-PAST
items.translation: Ah, [they] slept and slept,

items.transcript: yinya karrkay, nyulu bijarri-ny, bilngkumu bijarri-ny.
items.translation: that child, he dreamt, dreamt 'of' a crocodile.
[He] cried out, and cried and cried.
A whole lot of people turned up,

items.transcript: torch mani-ny, balba-ny balba-ny balba-ny bed-ba
items.translation: [they] got a torch and kept flashing a light on the bed,
and peeped under [the bed],
nothing [there was] nothing.

items.transcript: Ah jinbal, nyaka nyaka! Ah quick see.IMP ...
items.translation: 'Ah quick, look, look!' [The child was crying out]
He had a dream.
It is close now, [it] is coming close.
[It] is coming close.
[The child] smelled the smell, the strong smell [of] crocodile.

items.transcript: N ganjin mayi mani-ny, nganjin dunga-ny-da.
items.translation: We got some food and then we went.

items.transcript: Kaba-nga-ku nganjin dunga-ny, dunga-ny, dunga-ny, dunga-ny.
items.translation: We went in the rain, went on and on and on.

items.transcript: Kaba-nga-ku warri-ny, baral-ba kada-ny maja-nga, bubu julbarr.
items.translation: [We] drove (lit. ran) in the rain and came to the road in the scrub; the ground was slippery.
My children were in the back of the Toyota.

items.transcript: N galiny ngayku dunyu jakalba nganjin Chris.
items.translation: My husband and I were in the front together with Chris.

items.transcript: lana kaykay-angka nyaji-ny warru-warru-ngku maral-maral-angka bubu julbarr-bi.
items.translation: The children, the boys and girls, saw the really slippery ground.
There was heavy rain
Shall we turn back?
The pastor came from there, [he] had turned back.

items.transcript: Nyungu pastor-mu motorcar kari daka-ny, yinya balay karrkay.
items.translation: The pastor's car could not go up, it [that] was low and small.
The pastor had turned back again.
We went and saw the slippery ground.
What shall we do?
The children got frightened then.

items.transcript: Nyulu nyaji-ny, Chris-angka, brake yijarri-ny, yijarri-ny-ku-Iu.
items.translation: Chris saw [the slippery patch] and put the brake right down.
[He] straightened [the car] while driving up.

items.transcript: Motorcar julbarr-warri-ny yarra, warri-ny-ku-Iu yarra, warri-ny jalama-ny, jalama-ny-ku-Iu buck-maniji-ny.
items.translation: The car slipped and went this way and that way and jumped, jumped and bucked a great deal.
They [the children] wanted to go on, [they] were not scared anymore.

items.transcript: Nyulu Chris kurrka-nyaji-ji-ny yajarn-Jl-ny jana-nka kaykay-anka, yajarri-ny.
items.translation: Chris turned back and laughed at the children, [he] laughed [about them].
We went on.
Chris looked and said:

items.transcript: Buckjumper ngana Ah buckjumper eh buckjumper

gloss.morpheme: Buckjumper ngana Ah buckjumper eh buckjumper

items.translation: Ah, buckjumper, eh! We are riding a buckjumper.
run repeatedly

items.transcript: Nganjin dunga-ny-baja, dunga-ny dunga-ny dunga-ny, nyaji-ny-baja julbarr.
items.translation: We went on again, went on and on and on, and saw again slippery [parts of the road].
The car was slipping this way and that way.
He kept driving the car on there.
[We] got up there and reached the top of the mountain.
[We] looked, and there was no rain any more.
The ground was dry then.
There was no rain at all and we went on and on and on,
and we came to that very place.
[We] stayed down there.
The name of that place [is] Banana Flat.
We were sitting and eating early in the morning.
[when] John Robert's son came.
[It was] a young man.
[He] called out.
[He had come] with a motorbike.

items.transcript: Wulman nyulu ngayku dunyu nyulu mujurr-bu dunga-ny yarra wangkar.
items.translation: The old man, my husband, had gone out for witchetty grubs up there.
We were having a good feed.

items.transcript: Warru yinya kada-ny John Robert-amu yirrka-ny.
items.translation: That young man, John Robert's [son], came and called out.
I said to Chris:
Chris, that white man up there keeps calling out.
[He] asked Chris: "You have come back?"
Yes, I have come back.
I brought Johnny's family along.

items.transcript: Johnny nyulu yinyay wangkarwangkar mujurr-bu dunga-ny.
items.translation: Johnny went up there for witchetty grub.
